newsitem.title: FRANCE: French government removes Paris police chief.
newsitem.headline: French government removes Paris police chief.

text.p: France's new left-wing government on Thursday removed the head of Paris criminal police, who was suspended for refusing to help a corruption probe into conservative Paris mayor Jean Tiberi.

Olivier Foll, 58, was transferred to the less sensitive post of police inspector general. A decree published in the official gazette said he was replaced by Patrick Riou, 50, formerly the spokesman of the national police headquarters.

The decree, prepared by Interior Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement, was countersigned by President Jacques Chirac, who was Paris mayor until 1995 when Tiberi, his deputy and close associate, took over.
The case was a test of the "cohabitation" between the conservative president and the Socialist-led government.
The previous conservative government kept Foll in his job in an open challenge to courts which had suspended his investigative capacities.
The supreme court in February upheld a six-month suspension on Foll after he ordered his men to refuse to help an investigating magistrate search Tiberi's home last year.
Magistrate Eric Halphen was looking for evidence in a far-reaching investigation into alleged illicit funding of Chirac's Gaullist RPR party through rake-offs on public housing contracts.
